[[AFL–NFL merger]]; entering the 2024 season, the team is valued at over US$4.85 billion. After Hunt's death in 2006, his wife, Norma, and children became legal owners of the team. After Norma's death in 2023, the Hunt children inherited her stake in the franchise. [[Clark Hunt]], one of the Hunts' children, has served as chairman and CEO since 2006 and is the ultimate authority over personnel decisions. He is also the team representative at league owner meetings. The Chiefs were victorious and won three AFL championships, in [[1962 Dallas Texans season|1962]], [[1966 Kansas City Chiefs season|1966]], and [[1969 Kansas City Chiefs season|1969]],{{Cite web |last=Shuck |first=Barry |date=May 27, 2013 |title=The 1969 Kansas City Chiefs: Two Championships in One Season |url=https://bleacherreport.com/articles/1653179-two-championships-in-one-season-1969-kansas-city-chiefs |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220325131526/https://bleacherreport.com/articles/1653179-two-championships-in-one-season-1969-kansas-city-chiefs |archive-date=March 25, 2022 |access-date=March 25, 2022 |website=Bleacher Report}} and were the second AFL team (after the [[1968 New York Jets season|New York Jets]]) to defeat an NFL team in a [[Super Bowl]] when they defeated the [[1969 Minnesota Vikings season|Minnesota Vikings]] in [[Super Bowl IV]], which was the final game before the league merger went into full effect. The Chiefs were also the second team, after the [[1967 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]] (whom they played in [[Super Bowl I]]), to appear in more than one Super Bowl (and the first AFL team to do so) and the first to appear in the championship game in two different decades. Despite this post-season success, the team failed to find success in the playoffs for decades, including losing ten of eleven playoff games from [[1993–94 NFL playoffs#AFC: Buffalo Bills 30, Kansas City Chiefs 13|1993]] to [[2018 Kansas City Chiefs season|2018]], which included an eight-game losing streak. Since then, the Chiefs have risen to [[Dynasty (sports)|dynastic]] performance under [[Head coach#American football|head coach]] [[Andy Reid]], [[quarterback]] [[Patrick Mahomes]], [[tight end]] [[Travis Kelce]], and [[defensive tackle]] [[Chris Jones (defensive tackle, born 1994)|Chris Jones]], appearing in four Super Bowls since [[2019 Kansas City Chiefs season|2019]] and being victorious in three: [[Super Bowl LIV|LIV]], [[Super Bowl LVII|LVII]], and [[Super Bowl LVIII|LVIII]].{{Cite news |last=Brewer |first=Jerry |date=February 10, 2023 |title=Perspective {{!}} The Patrick Mahomes era is only beginning. establish a professional football league that would [[Rivalry|rival]] the [[National Football League]].{{cite web |title=Pro Football Hall of Fame: Kansas City Chiefs |url=http://www.profootballhof.com/teams/kansas-city-chiefs/team-history/ |publisher=Pro Football Hall of Fame |access-date=January 22, 2016 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126011856/http://www.profootballhof.com/teams/kansas-city-chiefs/team-history/ |archive-date=January 26, 2016}}{{cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200705055454/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=za0eZR4Qj38 |url-status=live}} Hunt's desire to secure a football team was heightened after watching the [[1958 NFL Championship Game]] between the [[New York Giants]] and [[Baltimore Colts]].Althaus, p. 35 After unsuccessful attempts to purchase and relocate the NFL's [[Chicago Cardinals (NFL, 1920–59)|Chicago Cardinals]] to his hometown of [[Dallas, Texas]],{{cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs History – 1960s |url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/history/60s/ |website=Chiefs.com |access-date=December 31, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080609053609/http://www.kcchiefs.com/history/60s/ |archive-date=June 9, 2008}} Hunt went to the NFL and asked to create an expansion franchise in Dallas. The NFL turned him down, so Hunt then established the [[American Football League]] and started his own team, the [[History of the Kansas City Chiefs#Early years in Dallas|Dallas Texans]], to begin play in 1960. Hunt hired a little-known assistant coach from the [[Miami Hurricanes football|University of Miami football team]], [[Hank Stram]], to be the team's head coach after the job offer was declined by [[Bud Wilkinson]] and [[Tom Landry]]. After Stram was hired, [[Don Klosterman (American football)|Don Klosterman]] was hired as head scout, and was credited by many for bringing a wealth of talent to the Texans after luring it away from the NFL, often hiding players and using creative means to land them. The Texans shared the [[Cotton Bowl (stadium)|Cotton Bowl]] with the NFL's [[Dallas Cowboys]] for three seasons. The Texans were to have exclusive access to the stadium until the NFL put an expansion team, the Dallas Cowboys, there. While the team averaged a league-best 24,500 at the Cotton Bowl, the Texans gained less attention due to the AFL's relatively lower profile compared to the NFL's. In the franchise's first two seasons, the team managed only an 8–6 and 6–8 record, respectively.{{cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs Franchise Encyclopedia |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/ |publisher=Pro Football Reference |access-date=January 11, 2009 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090119171848/http://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/ |archive-date=January 19, 2009}} In their third season, the Texans tallied an 11–3 record and a berth in the team's first [[American Football League playoffs|American Football League Championship Game]], against the [[Houston Oilers]]. The game was broadcast nationally on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] and the Texans defeated the Oilers 20–17 in double overtime. The game lasted 77 minutes and 54 seconds, which, at the time, was the longest game in the history of professional American Football. It is still the longest championship game in American Football League history. It turned out to be the last game the team would play as the Dallas Texans. Despite competing against a Cowboys team that managed only a 9–28–3 record in their first three seasons, Hunt decided that the [[Dallas–Fort Worth Metroplex|Dallas–Fort Worth]] [[media market]] just couldn't sustain two professional football franchises.{{cite news |last=Kuhbander |first=Brad |title=Kuhbander: This Week in Chiefs History |url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/2008/02/08/kuhbander_this_week_in_chiefs_history34/ |website=Chiefs.com |date=February 8, 2008 |access-date=January 10, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219105414/http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/2008/02/08/kuhbander_this_week_in_chiefs_history34/ |archive-date=February 19, 2008}} He considered moving the Texans to either [[Atlanta]] or [[Miami]] for the 1963 season. He was ultimately swayed by an offer from [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]] Mayor [[Harold Roe Bartle]].Gruver, p. 103 Bartle promised to triple the franchise's season ticket sales and expand the seating capacity of [[Municipal Stadium (Kansas City, Missouri)|Municipal Stadium]] to accommodate the team. Hunt agreed to [[Relocation of professional sports teams|relocate]] the franchise to Kansas City on May 22, 1963, and on May 26, the team was renamed the [[1963 Kansas City Chiefs season|Kansas City Chiefs]]. Hunt and head coach [[Hank Stram]] initially planned to retain the Texans name, but a fan contest determined the new "Chiefs" name in honor of Mayor Bartle's nickname that he acquired in his professional role as Scout Executive of the St. Joseph and Kansas City Boy Scout Councils, and founder of the Scouting Society, the [[Tribe of Mic-O-Say]]. Despite the historical use of Native American features, it has been acknowledged that the team's naming was not a direct reference to Native Americans but only to Bartle's nickname "Chief".{{Cite news Raiders]]), and the most AFL Championships (three). The team's dominance helped Lamar Hunt become a central figure in negotiations with NFL Commissioner [[Pete Rozelle]] to agree on an [[AFL–NFL merger]].Maske, p. 325 In the meetings between the two leagues, a [[Professional American football championship games|merged league championship game]] was agreed to be played in January 1967 following the conclusion of the leagues' respective 1966 seasons. Hunt insisted on calling the game the "Super Bowl" after seeing his children playing with a popular toy at the time, a [[Super Ball]].{{Cite news |last=Huppke |first=Rex W. |date=January 30, 2007 |title=Legends of the Bowl |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-2007-01-30-0701300052-story.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.today/20220605203842/https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-2007-01-30-0701300052-story.html |archive-date=June 5, 2022 |access-date=June 5, 2022 |work=Chicago Tribune |quote=Lamar Hunt, who died in December, coined the term Super Bowl in the late 1960s after watching his kids play with a Super Ball, the bouncy creation of iconic toy manufacturer Wham-O.}} While the first few games were designated the "AFL–NFL World Championship Game", the Super Bowl name became its officially licensed title in years to come.{{Cite web |last=DeArdo |first=Bryan |date=February 6, 2024 |title=Why is it called the Super Bowl? NFL title game's name was birthed by child's toy, Lamar Hunt's wit |url=https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/why-is-it-called-the-super-bowl-nfl-title-games-name-was-birthed-by-childs-toy-lamar-hunts-wit/ |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=CBSSports.com |language=en}} {{multiple image |align=right |direction=horizontal |footer=The Chiefs topped the Raiders in the [[1969 American Football League Championship Game|1969 AFL championship game]] (''left'') and went on to defeat the Vikings in Super Bowl IV (''right'') |footer_align=left |image1=1986 Jeno's Pizza - 49 - Robert Holmes.jpg |width1=140 |image2 =1986 Jeno's Pizza - 50 - Buck Buchanan and Curley Culp.jpg |width2=140 }} The Chiefs cruised to an 11–2–1 record in 1966, and defeated the defending AFL Champion [[Buffalo Bills]] in the AFL Championship Game.Gruver, p. 167 The Chiefs were invited to play the NFL's league champion [[Green Bay Packers]] in [[Super Bowl I|the first AFL–NFL World Championship Game]]. Kansas City and Green Bay played a close game for the first half, but Green Bay took control in the final two quarters, winning the game by a score of 35–10.{{Cite web |title=Super Bowl I - Kansas City Chiefs vs. Green Bay Packers - January 15th, 1967 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/196701150gnb.htm |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} The Chiefs lost the game but gained the respect of several Packers opponents following the game.Gruver, p. 179 The Chiefs' inter-league match-up with the Packers was not the last time that they would face an NFL opponent, especially on the championship stage. The following August, Kansas City hosted the NFL's [[Chicago Bears]] in the 1967 preseason and won the game 66–24. Despite losing to the division rival Oakland Raiders twice in the regular season in 1969, the two teams met for a third time in the AFL Championship Game, where Kansas City won 17–7. Backup quarterback [[Mike Livingston]] led the team in a six-game winning streak after [[Len Dawson]] suffered a leg injury which kept him out of most of the season's games. While getting plenty of help from the club's defense, Dawson returned from the injury and led the Chiefs to [[Super Bowl IV]]. Against the NFL champion [[Minnesota Vikings]], who were [[spread betting|favored]] by {{frac|12|1|2}}, the Chiefs dominated the game 23–7 to claim the team's first Super Bowl championship. Dawson was named the game's [[Super Bowl Most Valuable Player Award|Most Valuable Player]] after completing 12-of-17 passes for 142 yards and one touchdown, with 1 interception.{{Cite web |title=Len Dawson Stats, Height, Weight, Position, Draft, College |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/D/DawsLe00.htm |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080829163503/http://pro-football-reference.com/players/D/DawsLe00.htm |archive-date=August 29, 2008 |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} The following season, the Chiefs and the rest of the American Football League merged with the National Football League after the AFL–NFL merger became official. The Chiefs were placed in the [[American Football Conference]]'s [[American Football Conference West Division|West Division]]. From 1960 to 1969, the Chiefs/Texans won 87 games, which is the most in the ten-year history of the AFL.One game more than the [[San Diego Chargers seasons|Los Angeles/San Diego Chargers]], [http://pfref.com/tiny/RVKdE Pro-Football-Reference: In multiple seasons, from 1960 to 1969, in the regular season, sorted by descending date.] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.today/20120716110644/http://www.pro-football-reference.com/play-index/tiny.cgi?id=RVKdE |date=July 16, 2012 }} ===Hank Stram leaves team=== In 1970, the Chiefs went 7–5–2 and missed the playoffs.{{Cite web |title=1970 Kansas City Chiefs Rosters, Stats, Schedule, Team Draftees |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/1970.htm |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} The following season, the Chiefs tallied a 10–3–1 record and won the AFC West Division.{{cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs History – 1970s |url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/history/70s/ |website=Chiefs.com |access-date=December 31, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080609052751/http://www.kcchiefs.com/history/70s/ |archive-date=June 9, 2008}} Head coach Hank Stram considered his 1971 Chiefs team as his best, but they failed to capture their championship dominance from 1969. Most of the pieces of the team which won Super Bowl IV two years earlier were still in place for the 1971 season. The Chiefs tied with the [[Miami Dolphins]] for the best record in the AFC, and both teams met in a [[Christmas Day]] playoff game which the Chiefs lost 27–24 in double overtime. The Dolphins outlasted the Chiefs with a 37-yard [[Field goal (football)|field goal]]. The game surpassed the 1962 AFL Championship Game as the longest ever at 82 minutes and 40 seconds. The game was also the final football game at Kansas City's Municipal Stadium. In 1972, the Chiefs moved into the newly constructed [[Arrowhead Stadium]] at the [[Truman Sports Complex]] outside of [[CBD-Downtown, Kansas City|downtown Kansas City]]. The team's first game at Arrowhead was against the [[St. Louis Cardinals (NFL)|St. Louis Cardinals]], a preseason game that the Chiefs won 24–14. Linebacker [[Willie Lanier]] and quarterback Len Dawson won the [[Walter Payton Man of the Year Award|NFL Man of the Year Award]] in 1972 and 1973, respectively.{{Cite web |title=Walter Payton Man of the Year Winners |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/awards/walter-payton-man-of-the-year.htm |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} The Chiefs did not return to the [[NFL playoffs|post-season]] for the remainder of the 1970s, and the 1973 season was the team's last winning season for seven years. Hank Stram was fired following a 5–9 season in 1974, and many of the Chiefs' future [[Pro Football Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]] players departed by the middle of the decade. From 1975 to 1988, the Chiefs had become a team that rarely won, which provided Chiefs fans with nothing but futility.Althaus, p. 97Althaus, p. 101 Five head coaches struggled to achieve the same success as Stram, compiling an 81–121–1 record. In 1980, Coach Marv Levy cut future Hall of Fame Kicker [[Jan Stenerud]] for little-known [[Nick Lowery]], who would become the most accurate kicker in NFL history over the next fourteen years. In 1981, running back [[Joe Delaney]] rushed for 1,121 yards and was named the [[National Football League Rookie of the Year|AFC Rookie of the Year]].{{cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs History – 1980s |url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/history/80s/ |website=Chiefs.com |access-date=December 31, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080501122552/http://www.kcchiefs.com/history/80s/ |archive-date=May 1, 2008}} The Chiefs finished the season with a 9–7 record and entered the 1982 season with optimism. The [[1982 NFL strike|NFL Players Association strike]] curbed the Chiefs' chances of returning to the postseason for the first time in over a decade. The Chiefs tallied a 3–6 record and in the off-season, Joe Delaney died while trying to save several children from drowning in a pond near his home in Louisiana.{{cite news |title=Joe Delaney headed for Chiefs ring of honor Sunday |url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/2004/09/23/joe_delaney_headed_for_chiefs_ring_of_honor_sunday/ |website=Chiefs.com |date=September 23, 2004 |access-date=July 13, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050113113830/http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/2004/09/23/joe_delaney_headed_for_chiefs_ring_of_honor_sunday/ |archive-date=January 13, 2005}} The Chiefs drafted quarterback [[Todd Blackledge]] over future greats such as [[Jim Kelly]] and [[Dan Marino]] in the [[1983 NFL draft]].Althaus, p. 167{{cite web |title=Warrick, Klinger fell way short in Cincy |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/draft08/news/story?id=3326109 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=April 16, 2008 |access-date=June 5, 2022 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204040120/http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/draft08/news/story?id=3326109 |archive-date=December 4, 2008}} Blackledge never started a full season for Kansas City while Kelly and Marino played Hall of Fame careers. While the Chiefs struggled on offense in the 1980s, they had a strong defensive unit consisting of Pro Bowlers such as [[Bill Maas]], [[Albert Lewis (American football)|Albert Lewis]], [[Art Still]] and [[Deron Cherry]]. [[John Mackovic]] took over head coaching duties for the 1983 season after [[Marv Levy]] was fired. Over the next four seasons, Mackovic coached the Chiefs to a 30–34 record, but took the team to its first postseason appearance in 15 years in the [[NFL playoffs, 1986–87|1986 NFL playoffs]]. They lost to the [[New York Jets]] in the wild-card round. Despite leading the Chiefs to only their third winning season and second playoff appearance since the merger, Mackovic was fired for what Hunt described as a lack of chemistry.[https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/sports/sports-people-mackovic-released.html Mackovic released] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171213144449/http://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/sports/sports-people-mackovic-released.html |date=December 13, 2017 }}. ''The New York Times'', January 9, 1987. [[Frank Gansz]] served as head coach for the next two seasons, but won only eight of 31 games.{{Cite web |title=1987 Kansas City Chiefs Rosters, Stats, Schedule, Team Draftees |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/1987.htm |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}{{Cite web |title=1988 Kansas City Chiefs Rosters, Stats, Schedule, Team Draftees |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/1988.htm |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} ===Marty Schottenheimer era (1989–1998)=== [[File:MartySchottenheimer8-15-2013.jpg|thumb|200px|The Chiefs under [[Marty Schottenheimer]] had the second highest regular season winning percentage (.646) in the NFL during the 1990s.{{cite journal |title=A Decade to Remember: The NFL in the '90s |journal=NFL.info |date=December 20, 1999 |url=https://www.nfl.info/nflmedia/news/1999news/Decade.htm |access-date=February 16, 2023 |archive-date=February 16, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230216201505/https://www.nfl.info/nflmedia/news/1999news/Decade.htm |url-status=live}}]] On December 19, 1988, owner Lamar Hunt hired [[Carl Peterson]] as the team's new president, general manager, and chief executive officer. Peterson fired head coach Frank Gansz two weeks after taking over and hired [[Marty Schottenheimer]] as the club's seventh head coach. In the [[1988 NFL draft|1988]] and [[1989 NFL draft|1989]] [[NFL Draft]]s, the Chiefs selected both defensive end [[Neil Smith (American football)|Neil Smith]] and linebacker [[Derrick Thomas]], respectively.{{cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs History – 1990s |url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/history/90s/ |website=Chiefs.com |access-date=December 31, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709055422/http://www.kcchiefs.com/history/90s/ |archive-date=July 9, 2008}} The defense that Thomas and Smith anchored in their seven seasons together was a big reason why the Chiefs reached the postseason in six straight years.Althaus, p. 63 In Schottenheimer's ten-season tenure as head coach, the Chiefs became a perennial playoff contender, featuring offensive players including [[Steve DeBerg]], [[Christian Okoye]], [[Stephone Paige]] and [[Barry Word]], a strong defense, anchored by Thomas, Smith, Albert Lewis and Deron Cherry, and on special teams, Nick Lowery, who was then the most accurate kicker in NFL History. The team recorded a 101–58–1 record, and clinched seven playoff berths. The Chiefs' 1993 season was the franchise's most successful in 22 years. With newly acquired quarterback [[Joe Montana]] and running back [[Marcus Allen]], two former [[Super Bowl]] champions and Most Valuable Player Award winners, the Chiefs further strengthened their position in the NFL. The 11–5 Chiefs defeated the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] and [[Houston Oilers]] on their way to the franchise's first [[AFC Championship Game]] appearance against the Buffalo Bills. The Chiefs were overwhelmed by the Bills and lost the game by a score of 30–13. The Chiefs' victory on January 16, 1994, against the Oilers remained the franchise's last post-season victory for 22 years until their 30–0 victory over the Houston Texans on January 9, 2016.{{cite web |last=Teicher |first=Adam |title=Chiefs get first playoff win in 22 years, say they aren't done |website=ESPN.com |date=January 10, 2016 |url=https://www.espn.com/blog/kansas-city-chiefs/post/_/id/15555/chiefs-get-first-playoff-win-in-22-years-say-they-arent-done |access-date=August 25, 2024}} In the [[NFL playoffs, 1995–96|1995 NFL playoffs]], the 13–3 Chiefs hosted the [[Indianapolis Colts]] in a cold, damp late afternoon game at Arrowhead Stadium. Kansas City lost the game 10–7 against the underdog Colts, after [[placekicker|kicker]] [[Lin Elliot]] missed three field-goal attempts and quarterback Steve Bono threw three interceptions. The Chiefs selected [[tight end]] [[Tony Gonzalez]] with the 13th overall selection in the [[1997 NFL draft]], a move which some considered to be a gamble being that Gonzalez was primarily a [[basketball]] player at [[University of California, Berkeley|California]]. During a 1997 season full of injuries to starting quarterback [[Elvis Grbac]], backup quarterback [[Rich Gannon]] took the reins of the Chiefs' offense as the team headed to another 13–3 season. Head coach Marty Schottenheimer chose Grbac to start the playoff game against the [[Denver Broncos]] despite Gannon's successes in previous weeks. Grbac's production in the game was lacking, and the Chiefs lost to the Broncos 14–10. Denver went on to capture their fifth AFC Championship by defeating Pittsburgh, and then defeated the Green Bay Packers in [[Super Bowl XXXII]]. Coach Schottenheimer announced his resignation from the Chiefs following the 1998 season.{{cite web |title=Chiefs' Schottenheimer resignes |website=UPI |date=January 11, 1999 |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1999/01/11/Chiefs-Schottenheimer-resignes/6782916030800/ |access-date=August 25, 2024}} Following Schottenheimer's resignation, defensive coordinator [[Gunther Cunningham]] took over coaching duties for the next two seasons, compiling a 16–16 record. By the end of the Chiefs' decade of regular-season dominance, Gannon had signed with the [[Las Vegas Raiders|Oakland Raiders]], Neil Smith signed with the [[Denver Broncos]], and Derrick Thomas was paralyzed in a car accident on January 23, 2000. Thomas died from complications of his injury weeks later. After allegedly reading online that he would be relieved of duties, head coach Gunther Cunningham was fired.{{cite news |first=Doug |last=Tucker |url=https://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/chiefs/2004-01-20-cunningham_x.htm |title=Chiefs name Gunther Cunningham defensive coordinator |work=[[USA Today]] |date=January 20, 2004 |access-date=June 5, 2022 |archive-date=April 29, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210429225700/https://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/chiefs/2004-01-20-cunningham_x.htm |url-status=live}}{{cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs History – 2000s |url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/history/2000s/ |website=Chiefs.com |access-date=December 31, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080609095508/http://www.kcchiefs.com/history/2000s/ |archive-date=June 9, 2008}} ===Dick Vermeil years (2001–2005)=== Looking to change the Chiefs' game plan which relied on a tough defensive strategy for the past decade, Carl Peterson contacted [[Dick Vermeil]] about the Chiefs' head coaching vacancy for the 2001 season. Vermeil previously led the [[St. Louis Rams]] to a victory in [[Super Bowl XXXIV]]. Vermeil was hired on January 12.{{cite web |title=Chiefs Hire Vermeil as Coach |website=ABC News |date=January 12, 2001 |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Sports/story?id=99955&page=1 |access-date=August 25, 2024}} The Chiefs then traded a first-round draft pick in the [[2001 NFL draft]] to St. Louis for quarterback [[Trent Green]] and signed free agent running back [[Priest Holmes]] to be the team's cornerstones on offense.{{cite web |agency=Associated Press |title=Rams Trade Green to Chiefs |website=Los Angeles Times |date=April 21, 2001 |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2001-apr-21-sp-53881-story.html |access-date=August 25, 2024}}{{cite web |last=Grathoff |first=Pete |title=Priest Holmes reflects on how joining the Chiefs changed trajectory of his career |website=Kansas City Star |date=April 11, 2023 |url=https://www.kansascity.com/sports/spt-columns-blogs/for-petes-sake/article274199525.html |access-date=August 25, 2024}} In Vermeil's first season with the Chiefs, he led the team to a 6–10 record.{{Cite web |title=2001 Kansas City Chiefs Rosters, Stats, Schedule, Team Draftees |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/2001.htm |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} The team improved to a 8–8 record in 2002 but still missed the postseason.{{Cite web |title=2002 Kansas City Chiefs Rosters, Stats, Schedule, Team Draftees |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/2002.htm |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} [[File:Priest Holmes speaks with soldiers CROPPED.jpg|thumb|right|200px|As one of the league's top backs, in 2003 [[Priest Holmes]] set the NFL rushing touchdown record (27) for a running back in a season.]] In 2003, Kansas City began the season with nine consecutive victories, a franchise record.{{cite web |last=Skretta |first=Dave |title=Chiefs credit culture change with 9-0 start |website=The Topeka Capital-Journal |date=November 9, 2013 |url=https://www.cjonline.com/story/news/education/2013/11/09/chiefs-credit-culture-change-9-0-start/16378795007/ |access-date=August 25, 2024}} They finished the season with a 13–3 record and the team's offense led the NFL in several categories under the direction of USA Today's Offensive Coach of the Year honoree, Al Saunders. Running back [[Priest Holmes]] surpassed [[Marshall Faulk]]'s single-season touchdown record by scoring his 27th rushing touchdown against the [[Chicago Bears]] in the team's regular-season finale.Althaus, p. 65 The team clinched the second seed in the [[2003–04 NFL playoffs|2003 NFL playoffs]] and hosted the [[Indianapolis Colts]] in the AFC Divisional Playoffs.{{Cite web |title=2003 NFL Standings & Team Stats |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2003/ |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} In a game where neither team punted, the Chiefs lost the shoot-out 38–31.{{Cite web |title=Divisional Round - Indianapolis Colts at Kansas City Chiefs - January 11th, 2004 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200401110kan.htm |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} It was the third time in nine seasons that the Chiefs went 8–0 at home in the regular season, only to lose their post-season opener at Arrowhead. After a disappointing 7–9 record in 2004, the 2005 Chiefs finished with a 10–6 record but no playoff berth.{{Cite web |title=2004 Kansas City Chiefs Rosters, Stats, Schedule, Team Draftees |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/2004.htm |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}{{Cite web |title=2005 Kansas City Chiefs Rosters, Stats, Schedule, Team Draftees |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/2005.htm |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} They were the fourth team since 1990 to miss the playoffs with a 10–6 record. Running back [[Larry Johnson (running back)|Larry Johnson]] started in place of the injured Priest Holmes and rushed for 1,750 yards in only nine starts.{{Cite web |title=Larry Johnson 2005 Game Log |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/J/JohnLa00/gamelog/2005/ |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} Prior to the Chiefs' final game of the season, head coach Dick Vermeil announced his retirement.{{Cite web |date=January 1, 2006 |title=Vermeil to retire |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/news/story?id=2276661 |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=ESPN.com |agency=Associated Press |language=en}} The Chiefs won the game 37–3 over the playoff-bound [[Cincinnati Bengals]].{{Cite web |title=Cincinnati Bengals at Kansas City Chiefs - January 1st, 2006 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200601010kan.htm |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} ===Decline=== Within two weeks of Vermeil's retirement, the Chiefs returned to their defensive roots with the selection of its next head coach. The team introduced [[Herm Edwards]], a former Chiefs scout and head coach of the New York Jets, as the team's tenth head coach after trading a fourth-round selection in the [[2006 NFL draft]] to the Jets.{{Cite web |last=Pasquarelli |first=Len |date=January 6, 2006 |title=Jets, Chiefs strike deal; Edwards free to leave |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/news/story?id=2282716 |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=ESPN.com |language=en}} Quarterback Trent Green suffered a severe concussion in the team's season opener to the Cincinnati Bengals which left him out of play for eight weeks.{{Cite web |date=September 11, 2006 |title=Chiefs' Green out indefinitely |url=https://www.denverpost.com/2006/09/11/chiefs-green-out-indefinitely/ |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=The Denver Post |agency=Associated Press |language=en-US}} Backup quarterback [[Damon Huard]] took over in Green's absence and led the Chiefs to a 5–3 record.{{Cite web |title=Damon Huard 2006 Game Log |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/H/HuarDa00/gamelog/2006/ |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} [[File:Tony Gonzalez at 2005 Pro Bowl 050213-N-3019M-002.jpg|thumb|left|200px|10x All-Pro [[Tony Gonzalez]] has the most receptions (1,325) and receiving yards (15,127) in NFL history for a tight end.]] Kansas City was awarded a [[NFL on Thanksgiving Day|Thanksgiving Day game]] against the Denver Broncos in response to owner [[Lamar Hunt]]'s lobbying for a third Thanksgiving Day game. The Chiefs defeated the Broncos 19–10 in the first Thanksgiving Day game in Kansas City since 1969. Hunt was hospitalized at the time of the game and died weeks later on December 13 due to complications of [[prostate cancer]]. The Chiefs honored their owner for the remainder of the season, as did the rest of the league. Trent Green returned in the middle of the season, but struggled in the final stretch, and running back Larry Johnson set an NFL record with 416 carries in a season.{{Cite web |title=NFL Rushing Attempts Single-Season Leaders (since 1933) |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/leaders/rush_att_single_season.htm |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} Kansas City managed to clinch their first [[2006–07 NFL playoffs|playoff berth]] in three seasons with a 9–7 record and a bizarre sequence of six losses from other AFC teams on [[New Year's Eve]], culminating with a [[Denver Broncos|Broncos]] loss to the [[San Francisco 49ers|49ers]]. The [[Indianapolis Colts]] hosted the Chiefs in the Wild Card playoffs and defeated Kansas City 23–8.{{Cite web |title=Wild Card - Kansas City Chiefs at Indianapolis Colts - January 6th, 2007 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200701060clt.htm |access-date=August 25, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} In 2007, Trent Green was traded to the [[Miami Dolphins]]{{cite web |title=Green goes to Dolphins from Chiefs in trade |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/news/story?id=2894600 |last=Pasquarelli |first=Len |date=June 5, 2007 |access-date=June 5, 2022 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010134524/http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2894600 |archive-date=October 10, 2007}} leaving the door open for either Damon Huard or [[Brodie Croyle]] to become the new starting quarterback. After starting the season with a 4–3 record, the Chiefs lost the remaining nine games when running back [[Larry Johnson (running back)|Larry Johnson]] suffered a season-ending foot injury and the quarterback position lacked stability with Huard and Croyle. When the Texans began playing in 1960, the team's logo consisted of the state of [[Texas]] in white with a yellow star marking the location of the city of Dallas. Originally, Hunt chose [[Columbia blue]] and [[Orange (colour)|orange]] for the Texans' uniforms, but [[Bud Adams]] chose Columbia blue and scarlet for his [[Houston Oilers]] franchise. Hunt reverted to red and gold for the Texans' uniforms, which even after the team relocated to Kansas City, remain as the franchise's colors to this day. The state of Texas on the team's helmet was replaced by an [[arrowhead]] design originally sketched by Lamar Hunt on a napkin. Hunt's inspiration for the interlocking "KC" design was the "SF" inside of an oval on the [[San Francisco 49ers]] helmets. Unlike the 49ers' logo, Kansas City's overlapping initials appear inside a white arrowhead instead of an oval and are surrounded by a thin black outline. From 1960 to 1973, the Chiefs had grey facemask bars on their helmets, but changed to white facemasks in 1974, making them one of the first teams (alongside the San Diego Chargers, who introduced a yellow facemask that same year) in the NFL to use a non-gray facemask. The Chiefs' uniform design has essentially remained the same throughout the club's history with only four minor changes occurring. It consists of a red helmet, and either red or white jerseys with the opposite color numbers and names. White pants were used with both jerseys from 1960 to 1967, and 1989 to 1999. Beginning in 2009, during the Pioli/Haley era, the team has alternated between white and red pants for road games during the season. Prior to September 15, 2013, the Chiefs always wore white pants with their red jerseys. The Chiefs do not have an official alternate jersey, although unofficial alternate jerseys are sold for retail. The Chiefs wore their white jerseys with white pants at home for the 2006 season opener against the Cincinnati Bengals. The logic behind the uniform selection that day was that the Bengals would have to wear their black uniform on a day when hot temperatures were forecast.Ferrin, Reid. It is commonly used for prime-time games at home. The all-red look also served as the basis for the Chiefs' [[NFL Color Rush|Color Rush]] design. ==Arrowhead Stadium== {{Further|Arrowhead Stadium}} [[File:Arrowhead Stadium (October 27, 2019 - 8).jpg|left|thumb|Exterior of [[Arrowhead Stadium]] in 2019]] Arrowhead Stadium has been the Chiefs' home field since 1972 and has a capacity of 76,416,{{cite web |title=Arrowhead Stadium |url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/arrowhead/ |publisher=Kansas City Chiefs |access-date=September 14, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090830024003/http://www.kcchiefs.com/arrowhead |archive-date=August 30, 2009 }} which makes it the [[List of current National Football League stadiums|fifth-largest stadium]] in the NFL. The stadium underwent a $375 million renovation, completed in mid-2010, which included new luxury boxes, wider concourses and enhanced amenities. The stadium renovation was paid for by $250 million in taxpayer money and $125 million from the Hunt Family. The stadium cost $53 million to build in 1972, and an average ticket in 2009 costs $81. [[Aramark]] serves as the stadium's concession provider and [[T-Mobile US|T-Mobile]], [[Anheuser-Busch]] and [[Coca-Cola]] are major corporate sponsors. A rivalry has also developed between Bills quarterback [[Josh Allen]] and Chiefs quarterback [[Patrick Mahomes]], with many comparing it to the [[Tom Brady–Peyton Manning rivalry|former rivalry]] between [[Tom Brady]] and [[Peyton Manning]].{{Cite magazine |last=Gramling |first=Gary |date=January 23, 2022 |title=Mahomes-Allen could reach Brady-Manning rivalry levels |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2022/01/23/mahomes-josh-allen-rivalry-is-the-new-brady-manning |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220729004330/https://www.si.com/nfl/2022/01/23/mahomes-josh-allen-rivalry-is-the-new-brady-manning |archive-date=July 29, 2022 |access-date=January 24, 2022 |magazine=Sports Illustrated}} As of 2023, Buffalo leads the series 29–25–1, but Kansas City leads the playoff series 4–2. Of the six playoff meetings the teams have contested, three were AFL/AFC championship games.{{Cite web |title=All Matchups, Kansas City Chiefs vs. Buffalo Bills |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/game_query.cgi?tm1=kan&tm2=buf&yr=all |access-date=August 4, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} === Cincinnati Bengals === {{Main|Bengals—Chiefs rivalry}} A relatively new rivalry for the Chiefs has formed in the 2020s with the [[Cincinnati Bengals]]. Prior to 2021, the rivalry was nonexistent. By 2021 though, the Bengals became a rising team in the AFC with the arrival of a healthy top tier quarterback in [[Joe Burrow]], the #1 pick in the [[2020 NFL draft]], who could go toe to toe with Patrick Mahomes.{{cite web |last=Mbu |first=Joshua |title=Joe Burrow opens up on facing Patrick Mahomes as he speaks out on NFL rivalry |website=The Mirror |date=August 6, 2024 |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/other-sports/american-sports/joe-burrow-patrick-mahomes-nfl-33400168 |access-date=August 20, 2024}} The Bengals beat the Chiefs in the 2021 regular season in Cincinnati 34–31, and then followed that up with a victory in that year's AFC Championship Game at Arrowhead, a game in which the Cincinnati defense shut the Kansas City offense down in the second half and kicker [[Evan McPherson]] hit a game winning field goal in overtime to advance to [[Super Bowl LVI]]. In 2022, the Chiefs and Bengals again met in the regular season, with the Bengals prevailing 27–24 and sealing the game off of a rare [[Travis Kelce]] fumble. The Chiefs again met the Bengals in the AFC Championship game that season. The Chiefs won the game on a walk off field goal and advanced to [[Super Bowl LVII]] thanks to Bengals defensive end [[Joseph Ossai]] hitting Patrick Mahomes out of bounds when Mahomes was scrambling for a first down, leading to an unnecessary roughness penalty.{{cite magazine |last=Scott |first=Jelani |title=Fans Debate Joseph Ossai's Game-Changing Personal Foul on Patrick Mahomes |magazine=Sports Illustrated |date=January 30, 2023 |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2023/01/30/joseph-ossai-personal-foul-patrick-mahomes-debate |access-date=August 20, 2024}} The two teams met again in 2023, but did not face Joe Burrow due to Burrow suffering a season ending wrist injury earlier in the season. To date, the Joe Burrow led Bengals are the only AFC team to have a winning record against the Chiefs since Patrick Mahomes became their starting quarterback. As of 2023, the Bengals lead the all-time series 18–16.{{Cite web |title=All Matchups, Kansas City Chiefs vs. Cincinnati Bengals |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/game_query.cgi?tm1=kan&tm2=cin&yr=all |access-date=August 4, 2024 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}} === Missouri Governor's Cup: St. Louis Cardinals/St. Louis Rams === {{main|Governor's Cup (Missouri)}} When [[St. Louis, Missouri]] had NFL teams, namely the [[History of the St. Louis Cardinals (NFL)|Cardinals]] and later the [[History of the St. Louis Rams|Rams]], a cross-state rivalry existed with the Chiefs; with a trophy being awarded to the winner of each game. In Reid's tenure, the Chiefs have never had a sub-.500 season, making the playoffs in 10 of his 11 seasons as head coach, winning the division six times, and twice having two consecutive Super Bowl appearances, and three wins. The Hunt family kept ownership of the team following Lamar's death and [[Clark Hunt]], Lamar's son, represents the family's interests.{{cite news |title=NFL team valuations: #20 Kansas City Chiefs |url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2010/30/football-valuations-10_Kansas-City-Chiefs_309072.html |work=[[Forbes]] |date=August 25, 2010 |access-date=September 15, 2010 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100928162827/http://www.forbes.com/lists/2010/30/football-valuations-10_Kansas-City-Chiefs_309072.html |archive-date=September 28, 2010}} While Hunt's official title is CEO and [[Chairman|Chairman of the Board]], he represents the team at all owner meetings.{{cite web |title=Clark Hunt, Chairman of the Board |url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/front_office/clark_hunt/ |publisher=Kansas City Chiefs |access-date=December 31, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080610031039/http://www.kcchiefs.com/front_office/clark_hunt/ |archive-date=June 10, 2008}}Herb, Kuhbander, Looney, and Moris, p. 6 In 2010, Hunt assumed role as [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] alongside his role as chairman of the board. According to ''[[Forbes]]'', the team began the 2024 season valued at $4.85 billion [[United States dollar|USD]], ranking them 24th among the 32 NFL teams.{{cite web |last=Teitelbaum |first=Justin |title=The NFL's Most Valuable Teams 2024 |website=[[Forbes]] |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/justinteitelbaum/2024/08/29/the-nfls-most-valuable-teams-2024/ |date=August 29, 2024 |access-date=September 8, 2024 |language=en}} Owner Lamar Hunt served as the team's president from 1960 to 1976. Because of Lamar Hunt's contributions to the NFL, the AFC Championship trophy is named after him.Herb, Kuhbander, Looney, and Moris, p. 411 He promoted general manager [[Jack Steadman (American football executive)|Jack Steadman]] to become the team's president in 1977. Steadman held the job until [[Carl Peterson]] was hired by Hunt in 1988 to replace him. Peterson resigned the title as team president in 2008. [[Denny Thum]] became the team's interim president following Peterson's departure and was officially given the full position in May 2009.{{cite web |title=Denny Thum named Kansas City Chiefs president |url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/2009/05/08/denny_thum_named_kansas_city_chiefs_president/ |publisher=Kansas City Chiefs |date=May 8, 2009 |access-date=May 8, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090515014705/http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/2009/05/08/denny_thum_named_kansas_city_chiefs_president |archive-date=May 15, 2009}} Thum resigned from his position on September 14, 2010.{{cite web |title=Denny Thum steps down from the Chiefs; Clark Hunt to be CEO |url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/article-2/DENNY-THUM-STEPS-DOWN-FROM-THE-CHIEFS-CLARK-HUNT-TO-BE-CEO/9128f532-9b7d-4870-8adc-22f415572cde |publisher=Kansas City Chiefs |date=September 14, 2010 |access-date=September 15, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917113401/http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/article-2/DENNY-THUM-STEPS-DOWN-FROM-THE-CHIEFS-CLARK-HUNT-TO-BE-CEO/9128f532-9b7d-4870-8adc-22f415572cde |archive-date=September 17, 2010}} [[Don Rossi]] served as the team's general manager for half of the 1960 season, resigning in November 1960. Jack Steadman assumed duties from Rossi and served in the position until 1976. Steadman was promoted to team president in 1976 and despite being relieved of those duties in 1988, he remained with the franchise until 2006 in various positions. [[Jim Schaaf]] took over for Steadman as general manager until being fired in December 1988. Carl Peterson was hired in 1988 to serve as the team's general manager, chief executive officer and team president. Twitter.com. Retrieved on July 29, 2013. ===Tony DiPardo=== From various periods between 1963 and the 2008 season, [[trumpet]]er Tony DiPardo and The T.D. Pack Band played live music at every Chiefs home game.Althaus, p. 86McKenzie, p. 137 The band was known as The Zing Band when the team was located at Municipal Stadium. DiPardo was honored by head coach Hank Stram in 1969 with a [[Super Bowl ring]] for the team's victory in Super Bowl IV. When his health was declining, DiPardo took a leave of absence from the band from 1983 to 1988. DiPardo's daughter took over as bandleader in 1989, by which time DiPardo returned to the band by popular demand.Althaus, p. 100 For the 2009 season, due to renovations at Arrowhead Stadium, the band did not return to perform at the stadium.
